Medieval probability-related terminology
2. Medieval probability-related terminology

Terms, such as the Latin probabilis were already in use in
the early Middle Ages and can, for instance, be found in Carolingian
texts on rhetoric (e.g., Alcuin, Rhetoric, 113). The ancient
authorities on the subject were Cicero and Boethius, whereas
Aristotle’s most seminal statements on probability-related
concepts became known only after the middle of the twelfth century
(see Cox and Ward 2006; Fredborg 1988, 150; Greenberg-Pedersen 1984).
Particularly significant in this respect were the introduction of
Aristotle’s Topics into academic discourse in the
middle of the twelfth century (but the full impact was not felt before
1200) and the new translations of Aristotle’s Nicomachean
Ethics and Rhetoric in the thirteenth
 century.[3]
 By the end of this century, Aristotle’s definitions had largely
(though not entirely) supplanted those of Cicero and Boethius in
scholastic thought. The impact of this change should not be
exaggerated because the notions of probability held by Cicero and, in
particular, Boethius were in significant respects close to those of
Aristotle.

The main probability-related terms in this period were
probabilis, verisimilis, credibilis,
opinabilis, and some expressions indicating frequency such as
ut frequenter, ut in pluribus, and
frequentius. We need to look carefully at the specific
meanings of these words and phrases before proceeding to concepts of
probability in a narrower sense.
